repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Irrigation and Drainage Community
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation and Drainage
            Community Development Project for Georgia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            consistent Government support is key for successful project
            implementation. Appropriate government policies have to be
            in place for an enabling environment to allow project
            interventions to work successfully. Without a suitable
            institutional framework to manage, operate and maintain
            irrigation and drainage infrastructure, investments in
            rehabilitation are important, but nevertheless of short-term
            impact. The project has disbursed well over US$40 million on
            rehabilitation and reconstruction of infrastructure over the
            past seven years, over 90 percent on higher-order works.
            Without these investments, systems would have likely gone
            out of operation. In a measure to assist smallholder farmers
            the government rescinded the land tax for landholdings under
            5 ha. An alternative to abandoning this tax in irrigation
            and drainage schemes would have been to retain it and use
            the money for maintenance of the physical infrastructure.
            This would then have provided regular maintenance funds and
            benefitted all farmers in the irrigation and drainage
            schemes. Having a land tax would also encourage landholders
            who are not using the land to sell it. Charging service fees
            in drainage schemes is difficult, as the benefits of
            drainage extend beyond plot holders. A fixed property charge
            to all property owners in a drainage scheme would be more equitable.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Irrigation and Drainage Community
            Development Project : additional IDA financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed additional credit and grant
            for the Irrigation and Drainage Community Development
            Project (IDCDP) for Georgia will help finance the costs
            associated with the restructuring of the project to urgently
            address reconstruction of flood protection embankments and
            irrigation headworks and conveyance canals that have been
            destroyed or severely damaged by unusually heavy spring
            floods in Georgia. There will be no change to the ongoing
            project activities. Most of the remaining funds have been
            committed, with a large number of contracts ongoing, and it
            will be important to complete ongoing activities as planned
            in order to achieve the original project development
            objective. The new component, to be implemented in parallel
            with the original components, will also be implemented by
            the Department of Amelioration Scheme Management (DASM)
            through its fully staffed Project Technical Unit (PTU) that
            has sufficient technical and fiduciary capacity.

display_title.display_title:
Georgia - Irrigation and Drainage
            Community Development Project : additional IDA financing :
            Additional financing

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Irrigation and Drainage
            Revitalization Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Irrigation and
            Drainage Revitalization Program Project for Georgia is to
            increase agricultural production and farm incomes by
            arresting further deterioration of irrigation and drainage
            infrastructure and keeping the operable infrastructure
            functional. The project has two main components. The first
            component focuses on raehabilitation and maintenance of
            irrigation infrastructure and drainage infrastructure as
            well as targeted rehabilitation of infrastructure for the
            national Amelioration Assistance Program (AA). The second
            component develops and strengthens irrigation and drainage
            management in AA service territories and finances operation
            and maintenance costs to AAs, provides financing to
            establish AAs, supports the Department of Amelioration and
            Water Economy in the Agriculture and Food Ministry (DAWE),
            provides technical assistance to begin implementing the Dam
            Safety Action Program, finances environmental monitoring of
            indicators that have been identified during the
            Environmental Assessment, and sponsors training and study
            tours in areas such as financial management and accounting,
            conflict resolution, governance, asset management, and
            operations and management planning. Project management and
            financing the Project Preparation Facility comprise the
            third and fourth components.
